Posts.Content: I had a mapping biopsy, but it was done to determine if I had PCa in the first place. It would seem to me, however, that in the grand scheme of things, the benefits of getting all the necessary data to make an informed decision about whether to treat, if and so, what treatment to use, would easily outweigh the speculative risk of some cancer cells spreading.
Posts.Title: 3D Mapping Biopsy

Posts.Content: I had a rising PSA (although not as high as yours) with 3 negative biopsies. When my PSA kept rising, my urologist recommended a saturation biopsy. That's a procedure where they put you under full anaesthetic and take 30 or more samples from your prostate. It's not too bad a procedure. That biopsy did find two positive cores with very small amounts of Gleason 6 cancer, so at least now we know what we're dealing with.
Posts.Title: High PSA and no cancer detected

Posts.Content: Djin: Turns out I was right the first time. The Confirm MDX treatment was cost free. My doc is part of a clinical trial. For what it's worth, I did get a very confusing $295 charge, but that turned out to be for something else. When I had my last biopsy, they took a swab from my cheek which is used to get a DNA sample to make sure the biopsy result you get is actually your biopsy. It's just a security measure. Turns out the company that does that test was out of my network. So they billed me, but at a discounted rate. My doc then showed me that I did sign something before the biopsy agreeing to that out of network charge, but I never read what I sign before a biopsy. Anyway, it all had nothing to do with the Confirm MDX test.
Posts.Title: ConfirmMDX test

Posts.Title: ConfirmMDX test

Posts.Content: I had a Confirm MDX test for free because my doc is participating in their trial. They look at DNA from non-cancerous prostate cells and give you two percentages: one, the likelihood that you have cancer that was undetected, and the likelihood that your cancer is aggressive. In my case, I already knew that I had cancer, but it was nice to see the very low percentage for aggressiveness. My doc says the early results from the trial are encouraging. However, this test is just one rather minor piece of information. No one would make any treatment decisions based on it. The primary goal of the test, I think, is to decide who needs a repeat biopsy when the first one was negative, but the PSA has continued to go up.

Posts.Title: ConfirmMDX test

Posts.Content: I have had a similar experience with some biopsies positive, and some negative, plus negative MRIs. I'm on AS, and my current doctor believes in a annual biopsy no matter what, and for that reason I am switching doctors. I got a second opinion from a very qualified doc and he said, in my case, biopsies should be every 2-4 years, depending upon other factors. There is no "official" position on how often to do biopsies under an AS protocol, so I'd recommend getting a few opinions from different doctors on what they would do in your case, and going with the one who you click with.
Posts.Title: Nothing found on second biopsy.....now what?

Posts.Content: I have had a similar experience with some biopsies positive, and some negative, plus negative MRIs. Posts.Title: Nothing found on second biopsy.....now what?

Posts.Content: The big worry seems to be infections. Any hint of a fever and I'd rush to the doctor/hospital. With blood, I usually give it a day or two and hope it turns brown. That usually means it's on the way out. My last biopsy I had red blood in my urine for 3-5 days; brown for close to two weeks. Everything worked out fine.
Posts.Signature: Age 63 Diagnosed with PC in December 2015 based on saturation biopsy 2 positive cores, Gleason 6, both under 10% Currently on AS All MRIs negative, both before and after diagnosis Three post-diagnosis biopsies, two negative, one positive, with two cores of Gleason 6, both under 10%.
Posts.Title: Blood after biopsy

Posts.Content: Before my last biopsy, I asked by doc if I could be sedated. He'd never offered it, but to my surprise, he said he could if I wanted, but my under propofil. The only downside is that I'd spend half a day doing the procedure and would have to have someone drive me home. In the end, I decided that 15 minutes of discomfort wasn't worth all that, but if you really struggled with it, insist on sedation. If you're doc won't, get another doc, as it clearly can be done!
Posts.Title: Novocaine shot to the Prostate

Posts.Content: Before my last biopsy, I asked by doc if I could be sedated. He'd never offered it, but to my surprise, he said he could if I wanted, but my under propofil. The only downside is that I'd spend half a day doing the procedure and would have to have someone drive me home. In the end, I decided that 15 minutes of discomfort wasn't worth all that, but if you really struggled with it, insist on sedation. If you're doc won't, get another doc, as it clearly can be done!
Posts.Title: Novocaine shot to the Prostate

Posts.Content: I have several of those biopsies. Seems like everyone reacts a bit differently. My doc doesn't sedate me, but he does inject lidocaine to numb the place where the samples are taken. For me the worst part is simply the presence of a probe where I don't particularly want a probe. To me it's quite uncomfortable and it stays there for the 15 or 20 minutes the procedure lasts. Note I didn't say painful; just quite uncomfortable. When the needle actually takes the samples you hear the machine snap, but it's not particularly painful. It's icky hearing the snap and waiting for it to happen, but as I said, it's not actually painful. About an hour after the procedure is over, when the lidocaine wears off, I feel considerable pain for a couple of hours. Then, by the evening, I'm good to go do anything I want. I'd recommend having whatever painkiller they allow with you at the procedure so you can take it, after it's over, as soon as you begin to feel some pain. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Ultrasound guided prostate biopsy (looking for what to expect)

Posts.Content: ANWANK: I was in a similar situation many years ago. I was 48 or 49 and my PSA rose from in the 2s to in the 3s. Plus my father had prostate cancer, so a biopsy was ordered and it was negative. The urologist continued to monitor me, and 13 or 14 years later, a tiny amount of cancer was finally located through a biopsy. The good news is that prostate cancer is one of those which, if caught early, can usually be cured. So, in the grand scheme of things, with his family history, the good news is you are getting careful medical treatment, and if at some point, prostate cancer is discovery, you'll have discovered it as early as possible.

Posts.Title: Prostate biopsy this month

Posts.Content: The problem is there are several tests and it doesn't seem like a consensus has arisen as to which is the best. My doc did Prolaris, which is not the one done in this study. Hopefully Prolaris is just as good!
Posts.Title: Some Low-grade Prostate Cancers Show Molecular Features of Aggressive Disease

Posts.Content: ASAdvocate: I tend to think my doc is too cautious and Eggener is right, but it's tough because I have a long relationship with my doc. Ddayglo: I can't have an MRI guided biopsy when the MRI doesn't show any suspicious spots! Consult1: that's a very helpful article, as it finds that even every two years is likely more than is necessary.
Posts.Title: Question about active surveillance protocol

Posts.Content: I'm on AS because several biopsies have either been negative or shown a very small amount of G6 cancer. Here's my question: I just had an MRI which does not show any suspicious spots. Is there any reason to do a biopsy in this case? My PSA continues to rise and may be as high as 11 (it is more likely around 9). I realize that a rising PSA is a sign to check in again for a patient on AS, but, the question is, is there any reason to do a biopsy if the MRI is negative. I'm at a major academic medical center and my doc has pretty good confidence in the radiologists. Thanks,
Posts.Title: Question about active surveillance protocol

Posts.Title: Question about active surveillance protocol

Posts.Content: Folks, thanks for the responses, but perhaps my brief question didn't adequately convey my situation (and the fact I've been too lazy to put together one of the signature lines. Just so you won't worry about me: 1. I have already been diagnosed with prostate cancer; that's why I'm on AS. 2. I'm in a protocol with a doctor at Northwestern here in Chicago, and get second opinions from a doctor at the University of Chicago. So I'm under very good care. 3. I've had multiple biopsies including a saturation biopsy and several of the genetic tests. 4. I've had every test possible, so I'm not using an 8-ball! So I'm covered. To expand a bit, my question really arises from this. My doc is a very cautious fellow and wants me to have annual biopsies. Indeed. the last two were only 10 months apart because of a rising PSA. However, Dr. Eggener at the University of Chicago thinks my doc is WAY over testing me; that I only need a biopsy every 2-3 years years. So I'm caught not knowing what to do. Two docs recommending different AS protocols. In this context, my question arises, and I know there is no easy answer. If your MRI is negative, of course I know I have cancer, but is there a possibility that a new Gleason 7 or greater cancer has developed, or my Gleason 6 cancer has increased in volume (two triggers for treatment) when the MRI is negative? That's why I posed the question of whether yet another biopsy is useful if the MRI is negative. Final note: My doc hasn't made a recommendation yet. I pose questions here, however, so I can have a more educated conversation with my doc!

Posts.Title: Question about active surveillance protocol

Posts.Content: For me, the ejaculate took a month or more to clear up. It starts almost dark brown and slowly lightens in color. No need to hold off, however, the sooner (and more frequently) to get about it, the sooner it clears up!
Posts.Title: Had Biopsy Wednesday

Posts.Content: I not sure I ever asked how many samples they took in my saturation biopsy. I know it was over 30. I notice that yours was done after a diagnosis of cancer? Mine was done because of repeat negative biopsies, but a continued rise in PSA, so maybe there is a difference depending upon the trigger.
Posts.Title: Transperineal template biopsy

Posts.Content: I'm on active surveillance and it's time for another biopsy. My doc usually does them in the office (I've had several), which means you get a shot of lidocaine and that's about it. He will do it at the hospital with anaesthesia; the kind of twilight stuff you get for a colonoscopy. While doing it at the hospital will avoid the brief, but painful, period of time, it will involve most of a day instead of a quick in-office procedure. Opinions on what I should choose?
Posts.Title: Biopsy with or without anaesthesia?

Posts.Content: I had one many years ago. The insertion was pretty uncomfortable, but once it was "in," I relaxed and it was fine. I mainly recall that a nurse came to be before and asked if I knew how this procedure was going to be done. I did, but asked "Are there people who come here and don't realize what's about to happen?" She said yes, and I can just imagine the wide-eyed look on someone who shows up for an MRI and finds out right before about the "coil."
Posts.Signature: Age 63 Diagnosed with PC in December 2015 based on saturation biopsy 2 positive cores, Gleason 6, both under 10% Currently on AS All MRIs negative, both before and after diagnosis Three post-diagnosis biopsies, two negative, one positive, with two cores of Gleason 6, both under 10%.
Posts.Title: MRI and endorectal coil

Posts.Content: It's interesting the variety of procedures. A nerve block does not appear to be an option I've been offered. The lidocane my doc uses in an injection in the rectum. It numbers the rectum for the shots, but provides no relief from the discomfort of having the device placed where you'd prefer to have no devices placed. I'm not sure what having a "local" refers to. Thanks for the responses so far.
